title: 114_hr1218
content: The Act may be cited as the "Personal Health Investment Today Act" or the "PHIT Act." Congress finds that almost 20 percent of American children aged 2 to 19 are overweight or obese, leading to increased healthcare costs. Research shows that investing in physical activity can reduce medical expenses, and offering financial incentives can encourage more Americans to be active. The United States lags in preventing obesity-related deaths, highlighting the importance of promoting physical activity from a young age. The purpose of this Act is to promote health and prevent disease by encouraging healthier lifestyles, providing financial incentives for healthy behavior, and increasing participation in physical fitness activities. Research shows that investing in physical activity can reduce healthcare costs and prevent obesity-related deaths, especially when promoting physical activity from a young age. Certain amounts paid for physical activity, fitness, and exercise are treated as amounts paid for medical care. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include qualified sports and fitness expenses as amounts paid for medical care. This includes membership at a fitness facility, participation in physical exercise programs, and equipment for physical activity. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 now includes qualified sports and fitness expenses as part of medical care. This covers membership at a fitness facility, participation in physical exercise programs, and equipment for physical activity, with a maximum limit of $1,000 per taxpayer ($2,000 for joint returns or heads of household). A fitness facility is defined as a place that offers physical exercise programs or facilities for physical fitness development. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 now includes qualified sports and fitness expenses as part of medical care, covering membership at a fitness facility, participation in physical exercise programs, and equipment for physical activity. A fitness facility must meet specific criteria, including not being a private club, not offering certain recreational facilities, and being compliant with anti-discrimination laws. The curr_chunk discusses the treatment of exercise videos, books, and similar materials as qualified sports and fitness expenses if they provide instruction in physical exercise. It also outlines limitations for sports and fitness equipment, specifying that such equipment must be used exclusively for fitness activities, not be apparel or footwear, and be related to physical activity programs. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after the date of the enactment of this Act, specifically regarding the treatment of sports and fitness equipment expenses in physical activity programs.
